content: SHORT TITLE; FINDINGS. The Congressional Hunger Fellows Act of 1997, named after Bill Emerson and George T. (Mickey) Leland, recognizes the need for individuals dedicated to addressing hunger and implementing solutions. The Congressional Hunger Fellows Act of 1997, named after Bill Emerson and George T. (Mickey) Leland, honors their compassion for those in need, public service, and political talents. Emerson and Leland's dedication to helping the hungry and poor inspired others to work towards equality and justice. Despite political differences, they maintained a strong friendship and collaborated to encourage future leaders to serve others. Creating a fellowship program in their memory aims to train future leaders in humanitarian service. SEC. 2. ESTABLISHMENT; BOARD OF TRUSTEES. The Congressional Hunger Fellows Program is established as an independent entity under the executive branch. It is supervised by a Board of Trustees composed of 7 voting members appointed by the President in consultation with congressional leaders. The Board of Trustees for the Congressional Hunger Fellows Program consists of 7 members appointed by the President. Members serve a 4-year term, and vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. Vacancies do not affect the Board's ability to carry out its duties. The Board of Trustees for the Congressional Hunger Fellows Program consists of 7 members appointed by the President. Vacancies are filled for the remainder of the predecessor's term. The Board elects a Chairperson at its first meeting. Members do not receive compensation but may be reimbursed for travel expenses. The Congressional Hunger Fellows Program is overseen by a Board of Trustees appointed by the President. The Board elects a Chairperson and members may be reimbursed for travel expenses. The Congressional Hunger Fellows Program aims to encourage future leaders to pursue careers in humanitarian service, increase awareness of public service importance, and provide training opportunities. The Program is authorized to develop fellowships, activities, and services to fulfill its purposes, including the Bill Emerson Hunger Fellowship. The Bill Emerson Hunger Fellowship focuses on domestic hunger and humanitarian needs, while the Mickey Leland Hunger Fellowship addresses international hunger and humanitarian needs. The fellowships provide education and training to improve humanitarian conditions and help individuals suffering from hunger through direct service and policy development experiences. The Program conducts evaluations of the fellowships under this Act. SEC. 4. TERMS OF FELLOWSHIPS. The fellowship period is up to 24 months. Fellows are selected through a nationwide competition based on career aspirations and potential in humanitarian service. The Board determines the educational award and living allowance for successful applicants. Recipients of fellowships from the Bill Emerson Hunger Fellowship and the Mickey Leland Hunger Fellowship are respectively known as "Emerson Fellows" and "Leland Fellows". Establishment of the Congressional Hunger Fellows Trust Fund (referred to as the "Fund") in the Treasury of the United States, consisting of appropriated amounts, investment by the Secretary of the Treasury in interest-bearing obligations, and crediting of interest and proceeds to the Fund. Expenditures and audit procedures are outlined. The Secretary of the Treasury transfers necessary funds to the Program from specified amounts. However, funds appropriated to the Fund under section 9 cannot be transferred. The Comptroller General conducts an annual audit of the Program's accounts and is provided access to all necessary documents for the audit. The Comptroller General conducts an annual audit of the Program's accounts and reports the results to Congress. SEC. 7. STAFF; POWERS OF PROGRAM. The Board appoints an Executive Director to administer the Program, who is a nonvoting member and cannot serve as Chairperson. The Executive Director's compensation is capped at the rate of basic pay for level GS-15. With Board approval, the Executive Director can hire additional staff as needed. The Program appoints an individual paid at GS-15 level to carry out its provisions. The Program can accept gifts, bequests, and hire experts for its work. The Program can provide temporary services under section 3109 of title 5, United States Code, at rates not exceeding the daily equivalent of the maximum annual rate of basic pay for GS-15. It has the authority to contract with and compensate government and private agencies or persons without regard to section 3709 of the Revised Statutes. Additionally, the Program can make necessary expenditures to carry out its provisions. The Board must submit an annual report to the Secretary of Agriculture and Congress on the Program's activities. $20,000,000 is authorized for carrying out the Act.
